awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Safety and security for next-generation world-scale real-time medical systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Interoperable, reconfigurable systems of medical devices are the future of medical technology. They will improve care outcomes by catching common mistakes, reduce clinician cognitive workload by suppressing false alarms, and streamline and simplify continued care, especially when patients move between different medical facilities. As the penetration of "smart" networked medical technology increases, we will see increased problems with cybersecurity of such systems. This project is building the theoretical foundations and software prototypes to enable safe and secure real-time medical coordination in the presence of not only random faults, but actively malicious actors.

Medical and cyber-physical systems rely on real-time feedback and control, where microseconds could mean the difference between correct functionality and a fault, and ultimately, in medical systems, life and death. Since it is not possible to count on technology functioning flawlessly, especially with intelligent active attackers who may have access to medical devices or the network through which they communicate, this project seeks to develop requirements and best practices for "optimistic real-time" safety-critical systems, with built-in fallback to safe states if timing or performance guarantees cannot be met. The software and communication protocols will allow for global-scale medical systems, with real-time care independent of the location of the clinician or the patient, minimizing the chance of malfunction as a result of natural faults or tampering. The status of the system will be communicated to users without requiring specialty knowledge of security or communication protocols.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to improve the safety of medical and other cyber-physical systems through improved security and more integrated design approaches to both safety and security. Cybersecurity is a critical part of safe design, as successful safety engineering includes achieving the necessary functionality of cyber-physical systems (and systems of systems) while protecting patients and operators from environmental factors as well as unauthorized and potentially malicious entities. Because of the complexity of medical systems, we used interoperable, reconfigurable medical systems as a model for cyber-physical systems in general. Composable medical systems are increasingly used to improve care outcomes by catching common mistakes, reducing clinician cognitive workload by suppressing false alarms, and streamlining and simplifying continued care, especially when patients move between different medical facilities. As the penetration of "smart" networked medical technology increases, we will see increased problems with security of such systems leading to safety problems. When composed into systems, devices must remain safe individually, and the system they compose must itself be safe. Whenever composition involves device-to-device communication, the safety of the system relies on the security of devices, and of their intercommunication.

This project contributed to the fundamental understanding of medical application platform security design principles, access control requirements, process-driven security engineering, and ways to design and build intrusion detection systems (alarms) which can function even when the rest of the system has failed or was compromised by a malicious actor. We developed tools for creation of compositional trustworthy access control, "drop-in" authentication and access control software modules for legacy systems to enable safe and secure real-time medical coordination, and techniques to measure and model device state without pausing its workflow or modifying its hardware.

Driven by empirical observations and shadowing of clinicians in operational facilities, observing authentication and authorization workflows, we developed authentication and access controls tools with the clinical user in mind, explicitly taking into account how clinicians, facility administrators, and auditors (who define and review policies) do their jobs on a daily basis. The high-level concepts embodied by the tools are themselves conceived to ease deployment and integration without specialized security administration expertise or extensive security design knowledge. This encourages reuse and increases the probability of broad uptake (and thus improves the levels of infrastructure protection for everyone).

We developed novel hardware-centric methodologies that can detect corruption and tampering with unprecedented accuracy in already deployed cyber-physical systems. Our methods use measurements of microprocessor power draw or electromagnetic emissions to build and evaluate mathematical models of real-world workflows, and monitor correct execution of those workflows in running systems. We can derive these models even with limited to no knowledge of the internal design of the system being measured, and our monitoring methods are sensitive enough to spot malicious activity when the attacker tries to specifically avoid detection -- we assume the adversary knows the system, and knows they are being monitored. This "black-box" modeling allows deployment of security monitoring in legacy systems, where upgrade and modification may be too costly or when the original system design is lost.

We drew inspiration from safety as well as security, working toward safety-security co-engineering. To support improved security reasoning by safety engineers, and promote a deeper understanding of safety engineering by the security community, we engaged in extensive outreach and cross-disciplinary work, including collaboration with hardware and software safety engineers in academia, government, and industry. As a result, state-of-the-art access control, monitoring, and security engineering techniques have been incorporated into consensus standards development and safety engineering and analysis tooling. Moreover, the project lead to the development of courseware to present a more unified view of safety and security, introducing security researchers and engineers to the different modes of thinking pervasive among safety engineers, and vice versa.
